creations/orders of beings (bhūta = beings; sarga = creation, type, category)
in this world; in human existence as we experience it
the divine (daiva) and the demoniac (āsura) indeed — 'eva' emphasizes the completeness and exclusivity of this division
the divine has been described (prokta) at length (vistaraśaḥ) — referring to verses 1-3
the demoniac; the āsurī nature and its characteristics — what is to be taught next
hear from Me — a direct invitation to attentive, receptive listening

commentary.dadaji: The Lord pauses to draw a clear map before descending into the depths of the āsurī description. 'There are two kinds of beings in this world' — not to condemn or exclude, but to help us see clearly where we are standing and where we are headed. The divine has been described 'vistaraśaḥ' — at length, in loving detail — because the Lord delights in dwelling upon the soul's possibilities. Now He asks Arjuna to listen carefully — 'me śṛṇu' — with full attention. There is great love in this preparation, dear one: before taking a student into difficult territory, the compassionate teacher says 'Now listen; I am going to show you something important.' The Lord's voice is always the voice of grace, even when the teaching grows sobering.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This structural verse marks the formal transition in the chapter's logic. The Vedantic significance is considerable: the division into daiva and āsura is not a division into two groups of people but a map of two tendencies within consciousness itself. Every human being carries both vectors — the movement toward liberation (mokṣa-pravṛtti) and the movement toward bondage (saṃsāra-pravṛtti). The chapter asks each seeker to honestly identify which tendency currently dominates. 'Daivo vistaraśaḥ proktaḥ' — the divine has been lavishly described — because the Vedantic tradition always begins with the positive, with what is to be cultivated. The demoniac is now to be described so that it can be recognized, not so that it can be judged in others, but so that it can be uprooted within.
commentary.yogananda: The clear binary of this verse — daiva and āsura — reflects a perennial yogic understanding of the two fundamental directions of the human will. In yogic terms, the daiva nature is the upward movement of the prāṇa and consciousness — evolution toward higher awareness, cosmic consciousness, liberation. The āsurī nature is the downward pull — devolution toward material identification, sense-slavery, and the contraction of awareness into the ego-shell. Both are real forces in every human being, and the teaching of Chapter 16 is essentially a training in self-diagnosis: which force is guiding my choices, my speech, my relationships? The Lord's command 'me śṛṇu' — listen to Me — is itself a remedy: the moment consciousness turns toward the divine, the āsurī current weakens.
commentary.goyandka: This verse has the character of a sūtra — a thread-sutra holding together what preceded and what follows. The phrase 'dvau bhūta-sargau' establishes an exhaustive and exclusive taxonomy: all manifest beings fall into one of these two categories by their dominant orientation. The traditional commentators note that 'sarga' (creation/category) implies not a static condition but a tendency, a current — one can move between these categories through sādhana (spiritual practice) or through negligence. 'Daivo vistaraśaḥ proktaḥ' — the three verses of the daivī sampat were the vistaraśaḥ (extensive) teaching. Now, with 'āsuraṃ pārtha me śṛṇu,' the Lord signals that the next section (v7-18 approximately) will be an equally thorough analysis — but of the nature that the sincere seeker must guard against cultivating.

verses.sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च जना न विदुर् आसुराः । न शौचं नापि चाचारो न सत्यं तेषु विद्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: pravṛttiṃ ca nivṛttiṃ ca janā na vidur āsurāḥ | na śaucaṃ nāpi cācāro na satyaṃ teṣu vidyate ||
verses.translation: The demoniac people (janā āsurāḥ) do not know what should be pursued (pravṛtti) and what should be avoided (nivṛtti); neither purity (śauca), nor good conduct (ācāra), nor truth (satya) is found in them.

word_breakdown.meaning: what should be engaged in; right action; the proper domain of effort and activity (pravṛtti-dharma)
what should be abstained from; withdrawal from what is harmful; the path of renunciation
the demoniac people do not know — they lack the discriminative faculty (viveka) to distinguish right from wrong action
no purity — absence of śauca (the inner and outer cleanliness that was listed first among the daivī refinements in v2)
nor even good conduct; ācarā — right behavior, ethical conduct, respect for dharmic norms
nor truth — no commitment to truthfulness in thought, speech, or action
is found in them — a strong negative declaration: these three qualities are simply absent

commentary.dadaji: The Lord begins His portrait of the āsurī nature with the most fundamental lack: they do not know the difference between what should be done and what should be avoided. How sad, how lost — to live in a world full of choices and not have the inner compass of dharma to navigate by! The three absences that follow — no purity, no good conduct, no truth — are like three extinguished lamps. Without śauca, the mind is clouded. Without ācāra, relationships become cruel. Without satya, even one's own experience of reality becomes unreliable. Dear child, this is why the Lord has given us the śāstra and the guru and the sangha — so that when our own inner light grows dim, we can find our way by the light of the tradition. The āsurī person has cut themselves off from all three.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: From the Vedantic perspective, this verse identifies the epistemological and ethical root of the āsurī condition. The inability to distinguish pravṛtti (what should be pursued) from nivṛtti (what should be avoided) is fundamentally a failure of viveka — discriminative wisdom. Viveka is precisely the first prerequisite for Vedantic sādhana (sādhana-catuṣṭaya), and without it, no genuine spiritual progress is possible. The three absent qualities — śauca, ācāra, satya — correspond to the purification of the body, the purification of behavior, and the purification of speech/thought respectively. These three together constitute the foundation upon which the higher practices of meditation and jñāna must rest. Without this foundation, what appears to be spiritual practice is merely a sophisticated form of spiritual bypassing.
commentary.yogananda: The first symptom of the āsurī condition, as Sri Krishna describes it, is a collapse of discrimination — the inability to know what should be done (pravṛtti) and what should not be done (nivṛtti). In yogic psychology, this discrimination is the function of the buddhi (discriminative intelligence) — and the buddhi is clouded when prāṇa flows predominantly through the lower channels of desire and fear rather than through the suṣumnā (central channel) toward higher centers of awareness. The three absences — no purity, no right conduct, no truth — represent the successive collapse of the physical, social, and cognitive dimensions of the person. What remains when these three are absent is the raw animal appetite — powerful, relentless, and utterly without direction except toward its own immediate gratification.
commentary.goyandka: Verse 7 opens the āsurī description (which will continue through approximately verse 18) by identifying the foundational deficit. 'Pravṛttiṃ ca nivṛttiṃ ca na viduḥ' — they do not know what to do and what to avoid. This is the failure of dharma-jñāna — knowledge of what is righteous and what is not. The tradition identifies two sources of such knowledge: śāstra (revealed scripture) and sādhu-saṅga (association with the wise). The āsurī person rejects both. The three terms — śauca, ācāra, satya — are carefully chosen: śauca is the purity taught by the dharmaśāstras as prerequisite for all ritual and ethical life; ācāra is the code of right conduct maintained by tradition; satya is the metaphysical principle that aligns human speech with divine reality. All three are absent in the āsurī person — and in their absence, the entire social and spiritual fabric unravels.

verses.sanskrit: असत्यम् अप्रतिष्ठं ते जगद् आहुर् अनीश्वरम् । अपरस्पर-सम्भूतं किम् अन्यत् काम-हैतुकम् ॥
verses.transliteration: asatyam apratiṣṭhaṃ te jagad āhur anīśvaram | aparaspara-sambhūtaṃ kim anyat kāma-haitukam ||
verses.translation: They say: 'The world is without truth (asatyam), without foundation (apratiṣṭham), without God (anīśvaram); born of mutual union (aparaspara-sambhūtam) — what else is its cause but desire (kāma-haitukam)?'

word_breakdown.meaning: without truth; the world has no ultimate truth underlying it; no permanent reality
without foundation or basis; no moral or metaphysical ground upon which reality rests
they declare the world to be — 'āhuḥ' meaning 'they say/declare'; these are the demoniac's own words
without a Lord/God (anīśvara); no intelligent governing principle; the universe is without a conscious source
born of mutual union (of male and female); born from the coming-together of material causes alone; purely mechanistic origin
what else; what other cause could there be — a rhetorical dismissal of any alternative explanation
caused only by desire/lust (kāma = desire; hetu = cause); the universe and life arise from nothing more than sensory desire

commentary.dadaji: The Lord now gives us the inner voice of the āsurī worldview — and how cold and hollow it sounds! 'The world has no truth, no foundation, no God — it is born of nothing but desire.' This is not merely an intellectual position; it is a contraction of the heart that has stopped looking for the sacred in anything. When one truly believes that the universe is nothing but the churning of blind desire, the natural result is to pursue one's own desires as fiercely as possible — for if there is no God and no foundation, what should stop you? But beloved, consider: even the capacity to ask these questions, even the longing for meaning that this worldview is trying to suppress — is that not itself a sign of something beyond mere desire? The very dissatisfaction with the material is the soul crying out for its Source.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is the philosophical core of the āsurī worldview, and it reads remarkably like a summary of certain strands of modern materialist philosophy. The three affirmations — asatya, apratiṣṭha, anīśvara — correspond to: (1) ontological nihilism (no ultimate reality), (2) moral nihilism (no foundation for ethics), and (3) theological nihilism (no God or cosmic intelligence). The claim that everything is 'aparaspara-sambhūta' — born of mechanical mutual interaction — and 'kāma-haituka' — motivated by desire alone — is a remarkably precise description of the reductionist materialist position. Vedanta's response is not dogmatic assertion of the opposite but the direct inquiry: who is making this assertion? What is the nature of the consciousness that claims to know that there is no ultimate reality? The āsurī mistake is using the mirror of consciousness to deny the existence of light.
commentary.yogananda: This verse records what we might call the demoniac catechism — their confession of faith in the religion of materialism. 'No truth beyond appearances, no foundation, no God, nothing but the collision of particles driven by desire.' Sri Ramakrishna observed that the materialist says 'I don't see God' — but do you see your own mind? Can you see the very awareness with which you are looking? The āsurī worldview is a tour de force of selective blindness: it uses the most extraordinary faculty in the universe — consciousness itself — to arrive at the conclusion that there is no extraordinary faculty in the universe. 'Kāma-haitukam' — caused only by desire — is the āsurī person's honest and tragic self-portrait: they have reduced themselves to the one force they have refused to transcend.
commentary.goyandka: This verse presents the demoniac creed in the form of direct speech — 'āhuḥ' (they say/declare) — making it clear these are their own positions, not the Lord's assessment. The three-part denial is philosophically systematic: (1) asatya — they deny an ultimate truth (Brahman/Ṛta) behind appearances; (2) apratiṣṭha — they deny any moral-metaphysical foundation (dharma-pratiṣṭhā); (3) anīśvara — they deny any God or intelligent cosmic governance (Īśvara). Their positive theory is purely mechanistic: 'aparaspara-sambhūtam' — the world arose from the meeting of material elements — and 'kāma-haitukam' — motivated purely by sensory desire. The classical commentators (Śrīdhara Svāmī, Madhusūdana Sarasvatī) note that this is the Cārvāka (materialist) philosophical position, included here as a warning against its moral consequences rather than as a refutation in detail.

verses.sanskrit: एतां दृष्टिम् अवष्टभ्य नष्टात्मानो ऽल्प-बुद्धयः । प्रभवन्ति उग्र-कर्माणः क्षयाय जगतो ऽहिताः ॥
verses.transliteration: etāṃ dṛṣṭim avaṣṭabhya naṣṭātmāno 'lpa-buddhayaḥ | prabhavanti ugra-karmāṇaḥ kṣayāya jagato 'hitāḥ ||
verses.translation: Holding fast to this view (etāṃ dṛṣṭim avaṣṭabhya), these lost souls (naṣṭātmānaḥ), of small intelligence (alpa-buddhayaḥ), rise up as perpetrators of terrible actions (ugra-karmāṇaḥ) — enemies bent on the destruction of the world (kṣayāya jagataḥ ahitāḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: holding fast (avaṣṭabhya) to this view/outlook (etāṃ dṛṣṭim); grasping and not releasing the worldview described in v8
those who have lost themselves (naṣṭa = lost; ātmā = the Self); souls estranged from their own deepest nature
of small/limited intelligence (alpa = small; buddhi = intelligence); despite possible worldly cleverness, they lack the discernment that matters most
they rise up; they emerge; they come forth with power and capacity
perpetrators of terrible/fierce actions (ugra = terrible, cruel, fierce; karman = action); their deeds are destructive in scale
for the destruction (kṣaya) of the world (jagat); oriented toward consuming and annihilating what sustains life
enemies; those who do harm; literally 'not beneficent' — those who subtract from the wellbeing of the world

commentary.dadaji: This verse fills the heart with both sorrow and urgency. 'Naṣṭātmānaḥ' — those who have lost themselves — is perhaps the most poignant description in the entire Gita. They have not lost their bodies or their wealth; they have lost their ātmā — their very self, the thread that connects them to the divine source. And from that terrible poverty, they rise up — not in wisdom but in power — and their power becomes ugra-karman, fierce destructive action. The Lord is not speaking only of mythological demons, beloved — He is describing a very human pattern: the person who, having lost all connection to the sacred, turns their considerable energy toward using, exploiting, and ultimately destroying. Our response must be to protect our own connection to the ātmā through prayer, service, and study.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The verse brings the Vedantic diagnosis to its sharpest point. 'Naṣṭātmānaḥ' — literally 'those whose ātmā is lost' — is a striking formulation. How can one lose the ātmā, which Vedanta declares to be eternally present? The ātmā is not lost in reality but lost to awareness — covered by successive layers of māyā. When self-recognition fails utterly, the vacuum is filled by the ahaṅkāra (ego) running unchecked, which is precisely the āsurī condition. 'Alpa-buddhayaḥ' — of small intelligence — is equally striking: these are not necessarily stupid people in worldly terms. They may be highly intelligent by conventional standards. But their intelligence is 'alpa' (small, contracted) because it serves only the ego's agenda and cannot access the larger intelligence of Brahman. Vastly empowered ego-contraction is the formula for 'ugra-karmāṇaḥ kṣayāya jagataḥ.'
commentary.yogananda: The progression from ideology to action that this verse describes is one of the most important warnings in sacred literature. The materialist view (v8) is not merely an academic position — it has consequences. When held firmly ('avaṣṭabhya') and acted upon by those who have lost their spiritual center ('naṣṭātmānaḥ'), it generates 'ugra-karma' — terrible action — at civilizational scale. The word 'prabhavanti' ('they rise up') conveys not weakness but frightening power. Sri Aurobindo wrote extensively about this phenomenon — the 'Titan,' the asura, is not a feeble creature but a being of concentrated will and energy, precisely because that energy has not been surrendered to the Divine and turned toward liberation. It is like nuclear energy without a regulating principle. The world's destruction is the ultimate result.
commentary.goyandka: This verse draws the direct line from the demoniac worldview (v8) to its consequences in action. The causal chain is explicit: etāṃ dṛṣṭim avaṣṭabhya (holding this view) → naṣṭātmānaḥ (soul-lost) + alpa-buddhayaḥ (intellectually contracted) → prabhavanti ugra-karmāṇaḥ (perform terrible deeds) → kṣayāya jagataḥ (for the world's destruction). 'Naṣṭātmā' is glossed by Śaṅkara as those in whom viveka-śakti (discriminative power) has been destroyed. 'Alpa-buddhi' does not contradict worldly intelligence — one may be clever in the service of destruction. 'Kṣayāya jagataḥ' — for the world's ruin — elevates this beyond personal sin to cosmic danger: the āsurī tendency, when it gains power, threatens the very social, moral, and ecological fabric that makes human life possible.

verses.sanskrit: कामम् आश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भ-मान-मदान्विताः । मोहाद् गृहीत्वासद्-ग्राहान् प्रवर्तन्ते ऽशुचि-व्रताः ॥
verses.transliteration: kāmam āśritya duṣpūraṃ dambha-māna-madānvitāḥ | mohād gṛhītvāsad-grāhān pravartante 'śuci-vratāḥ ||
verses.translation: Taking refuge in insatiable desire (duṣpūraṃ kāmam āśritya), endowed with hypocrisy, arrogance, and intoxication (dambha-māna-madānvitāḥ), deluded (mohāt), they proceed — having seized upon false notions (asad-grāhān gṛhītvā) — as those of impure resolves (aśuci-vratāḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: taking refuge in desire (kāma); making desire the ultimate shelter and guide of life
insatiable; impossible to fill (duṣ = difficult; pūra = filling); desire that grows larger the more it is fed
endowed with (anvita) dambha (hypocrisy/ostentation), māna (pride/arrogance), and mada (intoxication/delusion from wealth, status, or power)
from delusion (moha); driven by the fundamental confusion that mistakes the impermanent for the permanent
having seized; having taken hold of; grasping tightly and not releasing
false/wrong conceptions (asat = unreal/false; grāha = notion, conception); ideas that are not aligned with truth
they proceed; they act; they set themselves in motion — with confidence but in the wrong direction
those of impure vows/resolves (aśuci = impure; vrata = vow, resolve, firm commitment) — they are committed, but to what is unclean

commentary.dadaji: The verse reveals the inner anatomy of the āsurī life with heartbreaking precision. 'Kāmam āśritya' — they have taken refuge in desire. Where the devotee takes refuge in the Lord — 'śaraṇāgati' — the āsurī person takes refuge in kāma. And this kāma is 'duṣpūra' — it cannot be filled, it only grows. The saints have always said: the way to happiness is not through satisfying desire but through transcending it — for desire satisfied becomes desire amplified. Dambha-māna-mada are the three ego-toxins that further poison this already poisoned well. And yet the most revealing word here is 'aśuci-vratāḥ' — they hold their impure purposes with the firmness of a vrata, a sacred vow! The form of commitment is there, but the content is corruption. Beloved, let us bring this same intensity of commitment — this vrata-energy — to our love for the Lord.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse gives us a precise Vedantic phenomenology of the āsurī inner life. 'Kāmam āśritya duṣpūram' — the āsurī person has made insatiable desire their ātmā-śakti, their fundamental operating principle. In Vedantic terms, kāma is a projection of ānanda (bliss) — the soul's authentic bliss is infinite, but when that infinite longing is directed outward toward finite objects, it becomes insatiable craving that can never be satisfied. Dambha (hypocrisy), māna (pride), and mada (intoxication) are the three forms of ahaṅkāra (ego) in its social expression: pretense toward others, arrogance toward self, and intoxication from external power and pleasure. 'Moha' — delusion — is the epistemological root of all this: the confusion between sat (real/eternal) and asat (unreal/impermanent). 'Asad-grāhān' — they clutch at what is not real — and 'aśuci-vrataḥ' — their vows and commitments are tainted at the root.
commentary.yogananda: The spiritual portrait in this verse is the exact mirror-image of the yogic ideal. Where the yogi renounces kāma as the great obstacle, the āsurī being makes kāma its deity — 'āśritya' means to lean upon for support as one leans upon God. Where the yogi purifies the triple ego-toxins through sādhana, the āsurī being is 'anvita' (permeated and accompanied) by dambha, māna, and mada — they are not occasional failings but constitutional features. 'Duṣpūra' — insatiable — describes the fundamental pathology of ego-based desire: it is structurally incapable of satisfaction because it is seeking the infinite in the finite. The tragedy of 'aśuci-vrata' — impure vow — is that the capacity for commitment and dedication (vrata-śakti), which is one of the soul's noblest powers, has been fully channeled into what is impure. The energy is impressive; the direction is catastrophic.
commentary.goyandka: Verse 10 continues the āsurī portrait with four sharply defined characteristics. First, 'kāmam āśritya duṣpūram' — they have taken refuge in insatiable desire; 'duṣpūra' (hard to fill) echoes the Gita's teaching in Chapter 3 (v39) that kāma is the eternal enemy of the wise, like fire that is never quenched. Second, 'dambha-māna-madānvitāḥ' — the three ahaṅkāric qualities that together constitute the social face of the āsurī character. Third, 'mohāt asad-grāhān gṛhītvā' — seizing, under delusion, what is not real (asad). The term 'asad-grāha' is theologically significant: it means they have taken hold of what is without being (asat), mistaking it for what is real (sat) — the fundamental Vedāntic inversion. Fourth, 'aśuci-vratāḥ' — their vows and firm intentions are impure. 'Vrata' normally denotes a sacred religious discipline; its pairing with 'aśuci' (impure) deliberately creates an oxymoron that captures the āsurī perversion of sacred forms.

verses.sanskrit:
चिन्ताम् अपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्ताम् उपाश्रिताः ।
कामोपभोग-परमा एतावद् इति निश्चिताः ॥
verses.transliteration:
cintām aparimeyāṃ ca pralayāntām upāśritāḥ |
kāmopabhoga-paramā etāvad iti niścitāḥ ||
verses.translation: Bound to immeasurable anxiety (cintām aparimeyāṃ) that ends only at death (pralayāntām), taking refuge in sense-enjoyment as the supreme goal (kāmopabhoga-paramāḥ) — they are convinced, 'This is all there is' (etāvad iti niścitāḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: anxiety, worry, restless thought
immeasurable, boundless, without limit
ending only at death/dissolution (pralaya = death; antām = end)
taking refuge in, clinging to, depending on
those for whom sense-gratification (kāma + upabhoga) is the highest (paramāḥ)
this much, this alone, no more than this
thus convinced, having firmly concluded

commentary.dadaji: Beloved, see how the Lord describes the torment of a life lived without God — boundless anxiety, with no relief until death itself. When kāma-bhoga is treated as the highest goal, the heart finds no rest; every desire fulfilled only births ten more. Sri Krishna is not condemning the demoniac soul with harshness but with compassion, showing us the precise anatomy of suffering so we may recognise it and turn away. As long as we cling to 'this is all there is,' the nectar of the Divine remains beyond our reach.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: From the Vedantic standpoint, 'etāvad iti niścitāḥ' — 'this is all there is' — is the definitive statement of avidyā. The demoniac personality has metaphysically foreclosed the Infinite: Brahman, the unlimited Consciousness behind all experience, has been denied. What remains is a finite bundle of wants and fears navigating a finite world, which is precisely why the anxiety is 'aparimeyā' — unmeasurable — because finite objects can never satisfy the infinite hunger of Ātman misidentified with the body-mind. The suffering described here is not punishment but the natural consequence of mistaken identity.
commentary.yogananda: The inner life of the materialist is a restless sea of cravings, each wave of fulfillment followed immediately by a deeper trough of want. 'Pralayāntām' — this anxiety persists until bodily death — because the soul has shut the inner door to the divine peace that passes understanding. Master taught that sense-pleasures are like salt water: the more one drinks, the greater the thirst. These souls have convinced themselves that the sensory surface of existence is its entirety, and so they never dive deep enough to find the inexhaustible spring of joy that waits within.
commentary.goyandka: This verse characterises the āsurī temperament by its psychic constitution: 'cintām aparimeyām' denotes the chronic, structurally unresolvable anxiety that arises when one has no transcendent anchor. 'Pralayāntām upāśritāḥ' — clinging to this anxiety-ridden mode right up to death — indicates that no earthly experience will break the pattern; only divine grace or a fundamental re-orientation of value can do so. The philosophical error is declared in 'etāvad iti niścitāḥ': the empirical world is taken as exhaustive of reality, thereby closing off the Vedic teaching on Ātman and Brahman. This verse is the psychological root from which the behaviours of the following verses spring.

verses.sanskrit:
आशा-पाश-शतैर् बद्धाः काम-क्रोध-परायणाः ।
इहन्ते काम-भोगार्थम् अन्यायेनार्थ-सञ्चयान् ॥
verses.transliteration:
āśā-pāśa-śatair baddhāḥ kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ |
ihante kāma-bhogārtham anyāyenārtha-sañcayān ||
verses.translation: Bound by hundreds of ropes of hope (āśā-pāśa-śataiḥ), devoted to desire and anger (kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ) — they strive to amass wealth by unjust means (anyāyena artha-sañcayān) for the gratification of desire (kāma-bhogārtham).

word_breakdown.meaning: by hundreds of nooses/ropes (pāśa) of hope/desire (āśā)
bound, fettered, tied
devoted to (parāyaṇāḥ), absorbed in desire (kāma) and anger (krodha)
they strive, they endeavour, they seek
for the purpose (artham) of enjoying (bhoga) desires (kāma)
by unjust, unlawful, improper means
accumulations of wealth (artha), hoards of riches

commentary.dadaji: Sri Krishna gives us one of the most vivid images in all of sacred literature: 'āśā-pāśa-śataiḥ' — hundreds of nooses of hope. Each hope we place in the world becomes a rope that binds us. Yet this bondage is self-chosen, not imposed from without. The Lord observes that kāma and krodha travel together: unfulfilled desire becomes anger, and anger drives the soul to seize by unjust means what it could not obtain by fair ones. How different is the divine path, where surrender to God loosens every rope and the devotee walks free.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The compound 'āśā-pāśa' is remarkably precise: āśā (hope, expectation) becomes a pāśa (noose, fetter). In Vedantic analysis, kāma arises from the superimposition of happiness upon external objects; the āsurī mind multiplies these superimpositions endlessly — hence 'śataiḥ,' hundreds of them. Krodha is the inevitable companion, as the Gita establishes in Chapter 2 (verse 62-63): frustrated desire produces anger. The cycle is self-perpetuating — injustice produces more enemies, more obstacles, more krodha, more desire for redress — a perfect description of saṃsāra-bondage at the psychological level.
commentary.yogananda: Every unfulfilled wish is indeed a rope around the soul's wings. The āsurī personality does not see that each hope placed in perishable objects ties another knot; they only feel the pull toward the next acquisition, the next conquest. Paramahansa Yogananda taught that desires are like waves: you cannot still the ocean by riding each wave to shore; you must dive beneath the surface to the calm depths of samādhi. The 'hundreds of ropes' are not external chains — they are the mind's own constructions, and only the wisdom of non-attachment can dissolve them.
commentary.goyandka: This verse logically follows the preceding one: those who are convinced that sense-enjoyment is the highest goal (v11) will naturally find themselves bound by āśā — the expectation of future enjoyment — multiplied into hundreds of entanglements. 'Kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ' identifies the two great vices Krishna named in Chapter 3 (v37) as the 'great enemy born of rajas.' The ethical consequence follows directly: 'anyāyena artha-sañcayān' — wealth amassed by improper means. Where kāma is unbounded and krodha is unchecked, dharma becomes the first casualty. These two verses (11-12) form a complete psychological-ethical portrait of the āsurī driven life.

verses.sanskrit:
इदम् अद्य मया लब्धम् इमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम् ।
इदम् अस्तीदम् अपि मे भविष्यति पुनर् धनम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
idam adya mayā labdham imaṃ prāpsye manoratham |
idam astīdam api me bhaviṣyati punar dhanam ||
verses.translation: "This has been gained by me today (idam adya mayā labdham); this desire I shall fulfil (imaṃ prāpsye manoratham); this is mine now — and this wealth too shall be mine in the future (bhaviṣyati punar dhanam)."

word_breakdown.meaning: this, today — pointing to present acquisition
obtained by me, gained by me
this desire, this wish (mano-ratha = chariot of the mind, i.e., a cherished wish)
I shall obtain, I shall achieve (future tense)
this exists, this is (present possession)
shall be mine (future possession)
wealth again, more riches in the future

commentary.dadaji: Here Sri Krishna places us inside the mind of the āsurī soul with extraordinary intimacy — we hear the inner voice of possessiveness in its purest form. 'Idam... idam... idam...' — this, this, this — the entire inner world reduced to a catalogue of acquisitions past and future. There is no God in this interior, no gratitude, no wonder — only accounting. Yet how recognisable this voice is! The Lord shows us this mirror not to shame us but to wake us, so we may replace 'mayā labdham' (gained by me) with 'tvayā dattam' (given by Thee) and find freedom in that surrender.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is a masterful depiction of what Vedanta calls ahaṃkāra-driven cognition — every experience is immediately processed through the filter of 'mine' and 'not yet mine.' Note the temporal sweep: past ('labdham'), present ('asti'), and future ('bhaviṣyati') are all colonised by the possessive 'me' (mayā / me). The Ātman, which is the witness of all experience, has been completely identified with the body-mind-ego complex. Śaṅkara notes that this kind of thinking — 'I am the doer, I am the possessor' — is the very definition of avidyā in its functional expression.
commentary.yogananda: The inner monologue Krishna transcribes here is one that advanced meditators learn to observe and dissolve. Every 'I have obtained' and 'I shall obtain' is a ripple of ego-consciousness on the calm surface of the Self. Master taught that the cure for possessiveness is to see yourself as the divine instrument — 'not I but God through me.' When this realisation deepens in meditation, the anxious inner accountant of this verse falls silent, replaced by a deep gratitude in which all things are received as gifts from the Beloved.
commentary.goyandka: Verses 13-15 constitute what classical commentators recognise as the inner soliloquy (sva-gata-bhāṣaṇa) of the āsurī personality, and it is remarkable for what it reveals by its very structure. Every sentence has 'I' or 'mine' as its operative centre. 'Manoratham' — the chariot of the mind — beautifully captures the runaway quality of desire: the mind races forward on the vehicle of want, never resting. The threefold temporal structure of this verse (past acquisition, future desire, present and future wealth) shows that the āsurī mind is never present — it is always grasping, never resting in what is.

verses.sanskrit:
असौ मया हतः शत्रुर् हनिष्ये चापरान् अपि ।
ईश्वरोऽहम् अहं भोगी सिद्धोऽहं बलवान् सुखी ॥
verses.transliteration:
asau mayā hataḥ śatruḥ haniṣye cāparān api |
īśvaraḥ aham ahaṃ bhogī siddhaḥ ahaṃ balavān sukhī ||
verses.translation: "That enemy has been slain by me (asau mayā hataḥ śatruḥ); others too I shall slay (haniṣye cāparān api); I am the Lord (īśvaraḥ aham), I am the enjoyer (ahaṃ bhogī); I am successful (siddhaḥ aham), powerful (balavān), and happy (sukhī)."

word_breakdown.meaning: that enemy (asau śatruḥ) has been slain (hataḥ) by me (mayā)
I shall slay, I shall destroy (future, first person)
others also, the rest as well
I am the Lord, I am the master/controller
I am the enjoyer, I am the experiencer of pleasures
I am successful, I am accomplished, I am perfected
powerful (balavān) and happy (sukhī)

commentary.dadaji: See how Sri Krishna catalogues the āsurī soul's five delusions in a single verse: I am the slayer, I am the controller, I am the enjoyer, I am the successful one, I am the happy one. Each 'aham' is a false claim — for in truth it is God alone who acts, enjoys, controls, accomplishes, and blesses. The devotee's response to this verse is simply to replace every āsurī 'aham' with 'tvam' — Thou art the Lord, Thou art the enjoyer, Thou art my strength and my joy. That inversion of ego into devotion is the essence of surrender.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse presents what we might call the full inflation of the jīva's ego — the āsurī soul has claimed for the finite self (ahaṃkāra) every attribute that belongs to Brahman alone. 'Īśvaraḥ aham' — I am the Lord — is in fact the highest Vedantic mahāvākya (Aham Brahmāsmi), but uttered here in complete ignorance of its true meaning. The āsurī soul claims lordship of a few acres, a few relationships, a small enterprise — while the true Īśvara is the ground of all existence. It is avidyā wearing the costume of jñāna.
commentary.yogananda: Five claims of the ego are compressed into this half-verse: power over enemies, power over the future, lordship, enjoyment, success, strength, happiness — all claimed exclusively for the small self. Yogananda taught that this is precisely the ego's programme: to appropriate all of God's attributes and apply them to the body-mind. The spiritual path is the systematic reversal of this programme — recognising that all power, all lordship, all true joy belong to the Divine within. Then the statement 'ahaṃ bhogī' transforms into something beautiful: the liberated soul enjoys all experience as God's own delight flowing through a transparent instrument.
commentary.goyandka: The structure of this verse is instructive: it begins with violence ('hataḥ śatruḥ,' 'haniṣye'), moves to claims of divine status ('īśvaraḥ aham'), and ends with the assertion of self-sufficiency ('siddhaḥ, balavān, sukhī'). The escalation is intentional — the āsurī trajectory moves from external domination to internal inflation. 'Īśvaraḥ aham' is the theological root of all subsequent evil: when the individual soul claims divine sovereignty without acknowledging the supreme Īśvara, all dharmic restraints are dissolved. This is why the demoniac nature is ultimately a theological problem, not merely an ethical one.

verses.sanskrit:
आढ्योऽभिजनवान् अस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया ।
यक्ष्ये दास्यामि मोदिष्य इत्य् अज्ञान-विमोहिताः ॥
verses.transliteration:
āḍhyaḥ abhijanavān asmi kaḥ anyaḥ asti sadṛśaḥ mayā |
yakṣye dāsyāmi modiṣye iti ajñāna-vimohitāḥ ||
verses.translation: "I am wealthy (āḍhyaḥ), well-born (abhijanavān); who else is equal to me (kaḥ anyaḥ sadṛśaḥ mayā)? I will perform sacrifice (yakṣye), I will give charity (dāsyāmi), I will rejoice (modiṣye)" — thus deluded by ignorance (ajñāna-vimohitāḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: wealthy, rich, prosperous
well-born, of noble lineage, aristocratic
who else is equal to (sadṛśaḥ) me (mayā)?
I shall perform sacrifice (yajña), I shall worship
I shall give, I shall donate (charity, dāna)
I shall rejoice, I shall delight, I shall celebrate
completely deluded (vimohitāḥ) by ignorance (ajñāna)

commentary.dadaji: How tenderly Sri Krishna adds 'ajñāna-vimohitāḥ' — deluded by ignorance — at the end of this boastful soliloquy. The Lord does not say 'wicked' or 'evil'; he says 'deluded.' Even the most arrogant soul is ultimately a lost child, confused about its own true nature. The āsurī soul even plans to perform yajña and give dāna — outwardly religious acts — but entirely for self-aggrandisement, for social status, for self-congratulation. True worship begins only when the 'kaḥ anyaḥ sadṛśo mayā' — who equals me — is replaced with 'sarvam khalv idaṃ brahma' — all this is Brahman.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse completes the inner monologue with a devastating irony: the āsurī soul even proposes to perform yajña and give dāna — the very disciplines the Gita recommends — but the motivation is entirely ego-driven, a self-display of superiority. This is the Vedantic concept of avidyā at its subtlest: even dharmic actions can be co-opted by the ego. 'Ko'nyo'sti sadṛśo mayā' — who is equal to me? — reveals that the āsurī soul has no genuine peers, no genuine community, and therefore no genuine love. The ego that inflates to divine size (v14) can have no real relationships.
commentary.yogananda: When the ego performs charity, it gives to see itself giving. When it performs ritual, it worships itself in God's name. This is the spiritual hypocrisy that Yogananda called 'ego-worship' — the most entrenched form of maya. The three verbs here — yakṣye, dāsyāmi, modiṣye — sacrifice, give, rejoice — are all genuinely good actions, but the word 'iti' ('thus thinking') followed by 'ajñāna-vimohitāḥ' ('deluded by ignorance') shows that it is the interior orientation that determines whether these acts liberate or bind. True yajña dissolves the sense of 'I am the doer'; the āsurī yajña reinforces it.
commentary.goyandka: This verse closes the three-verse interior monologue (v13-15) and its final attribution — 'ajñāna-vimohitāḥ' — is the key to understanding the entire passage. Krishna does not characterise the āsurī soul primarily as evil but as deluded. Ajñāna (ignorance of the Ātman's true nature) is the root; the rest — pride, cruelty, injustice, false religion — are its branches. The mention of yajña and dāna is significant: these are Vedic prescribed duties, and even they are corrupted when performed without the śraddhā and the knowledge that the true beneficiary of all worship is the Paramātman dwelling in all.

verses.sanskrit:
अनेक-चित्त-विभ्रान्ता मोह-जाल-समावृताः ।
प्रसक्ताः काम-भोगेषु पतन्ति नरकेऽशुचौ ॥
verses.transliteration:
aneka-citta-vibhrāntāḥ moha-jāla-samāvṛtāḥ |
prasaktāḥ kāma-bhogeṣu patanti narake aśucau ||
verses.translation: Bewildered by countless thoughts (aneka-citta-vibhrāntāḥ), enveloped in the net of delusion (moha-jāla-samāvṛtāḥ), deeply addicted to sense-gratification (kāma-bhogeṣu prasaktāḥ) — they fall into an impure hell (narake aśucau).

word_breakdown.meaning: bewildered (vibhrāntāḥ) by many/countless (aneka) thoughts (citta), mentally scattered
completely covered/enveloped (samāvṛtāḥ) by the net (jāla) of delusion (moha)
deeply attached to, addicted to, hopelessly engrossed in
in the enjoyments/gratifications (bhogeṣu) of desires (kāma)
they fall, they sink, they descend
into impure (aśucau) hell (naraka)

commentary.dadaji: Sri Krishna uses the image of a net — moha-jāla — to capture the nature of māyā's entrapment. A fish in a net does not know it is caught; it simply swims in tightening circles. So too the āsurī soul, scattered across thousands of anxious thoughts, does not recognise its own imprisonment. The compassionate Lord describes this not to condemn but to help us see: am I too caught in the net of my own mental proliferations? Every moment of sincere prayer is a thread cut in that net, every act of surrender to God a wider opening through which the soul may slip free.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The three conditions described here — scattered thought, delusional covering, sense-addiction — form a precise Vedantic diagnosis of bondage. 'Aneka-citta-vibhrāntāḥ' is the opposite of the ekāgratā (one-pointedness) that the Gita prescribes; it is the dissipated mind of which Chapter 2 speaks. 'Moha-jāla' is the net of mithyā-jñāna — false knowledge — that Śaṅkara identifies as the proximate cause of suffering. 'Kāma-bhogeṣu prasaktāḥ' is the inevitable consequence: when the intellect is submerged in moha, it cannot discriminate between the pleasant (preya) and the good (śreya), and the pull of the senses is unresisted.
commentary.yogananda: The 'net of delusion' is perhaps the most potent metaphor in this section. In deep meditation, one begins to perceive this net as if from outside it — the countless mental threads, each one a habit of thought or craving, woven into a seemingly solid reality. Yogananda taught that the whole phenomenal world is such a net, projected by cosmic māyā, and that the yogi's task is to see through it — not by denying experience, but by recognising the divine Consciousness that sustains it. The fall into 'narake'śucau' — impure hell — begins not with dramatic evil but with this quiet addiction to scattered sensory living.
commentary.goyandka: This verse marks a transition in the chapter: the interior portrait (v13-15) now gives way to the result. The compound 'aneka-citta-vibhrāntāḥ' indicates that the root cause of the āsurī downfall is mental — specifically, the absence of concentrated, discriminating thought. 'Moha-jāla-samāvṛtāḥ' employs the beautiful image of the net (jāla): one does not notice the net until it is drawn tight. 'Narake'śucau' — impure hell — refers both to the post-mortem condition described in the dharmaśāstra literature and, esoterically, to the hellish quality of a life lived in constant desire and delusion, which is itself a form of hell regardless of its external comforts.

verses.sanskrit:
आत्म-सम्भाविताः स्तब्धा धन-मान-मदान्विताः ।
यजन्ते नाम-यज्ञैस् ते दम्भेनाविधिपूर्वकम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
ātma-sambhāvitāḥ stabdhāḥ dhana-māna-mada-anvitāḥ |
yajante nāma-yajñaiḥ te dambhena avidhipūrvakam ||
verses.translation: Self-conceited (ātma-sambhāvitāḥ), stubborn (stabdhāḥ), intoxicated with wealth and pride (dhana-māna-madānvitāḥ) — they perform sacrifices in name only (nāma-yajñaiḥ), with ostentation (dambhena), without following the prescribed method (avidhipūrvakam).

word_breakdown.meaning: self-conceited, self-honouring, thinking highly of oneself (ātman + sambhāvita = honoured)
stubborn, rigid, arrogant, unyielding
accompanied by (anvitāḥ) the intoxication (mada) of wealth (dhana) and pride/honour (māna)
they perform sacrifice/worship (yaj = to sacrifice)
with sacrifices in name only (nāma = name/nominal), i.e., empty ritualism
with ostentation, with show, with hypocrisy (dambha)
not following the prescribed method/rule (a-vidhi-pūrvakam = without proper procedure)

commentary.dadaji: Here we see the āsurī parody of religion — its outward forms preserved, its inner spirit entirely absent. 'Nāma-yajñaiḥ' — sacrifices in name only — captures the tragedy of religion reduced to performance. Sri Krishna is not dismissing ritual; He honours yajña throughout the Gita. But yajña offered in the spirit of dambha — show — is not yajña at all; it is ego-feeding disguised as worship. The great bhaktas teach that the only true sacrifice is the offering of one's ego itself into the fire of divine love. Until that offering is made, all other yajñas are, as Krishna says, in name only.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse describes the co-optation of dharmic forms by āsurī motivation — a phenomenon as relevant today as in any age. 'Ātma-sambhāvitāḥ' — self-honouring — is the opposite of the humility that Vedanta prescribes as a prerequisite for true spiritual inquiry (cf. 'amānitva' in Chapter 13, the first of the divine qualities). 'Stabdhāḥ' — rigidity — is the opposite of the viveka-buddhi that can discriminate and adapt. When ego (ahaṃkāra), wealth (dhana), and pride (māna) combine into mada (intoxication), the intellect is effectively anaesthetised — unable to receive the teaching of the guru or the grace of the Paramātman.
commentary.yogananda: Religion performed for show is one of the subtlest traps on the spiritual path, because it provides the feeling of spiritual life while blocking its substance. Yogananda often warned that the greatest obstacle to God-realisation is not gross sin but spiritual pride — the 'ātma-sambhāvitāḥ' condition. 'Avidhipūrvakam' — not following the prescribed method — points to the fact that true worship has an inner science, a precise method of opening the heart and stilling the ego, which no amount of external performance can substitute. The Kriyā practice is precisely the 'vidhi' — the method — that transforms religious form into living spiritual experience.
commentary.goyandka: This verse addresses the religious dimension of āsurī behaviour — completing the portrait by showing that even the āsurī soul performs the prescribed Vedic acts (yajña), but without the two essential conditions: proper method (vidhi) and proper spirit (śraddhā). 'Dambha' — ostentation — is identified in Chapter 17 as a quality born of rajas and tamas. The distinction between 'nāma-yajña' (nominal sacrifice) and true yajña is the distinction between ritual as social performance and ritual as an act of conscious communion with the divine. Śaṅkara emphasises that 'avidhipūrvakam' disqualifies the act at the root, since the śāstra-prescribed method is the channel through which the yajña reaches its intended cosmic recipients.

verses.sanskrit:
अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः ।
माम् आत्म-पर-देहेषु प्रद्विषन्तोऽभ्यसूयकाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
ahaṅkāram balam darpam kāmam krodham ca saṃśritāḥ |
mām ātma-para-deheṣu pradviṣantaḥ abhyasūyakāḥ ||
verses.translation: Taking refuge in ego (ahaṅkāra), force (bala), arrogance (darpa), desire (kāma), and anger (krodha) — hating Me (mām) in their own body and in others' bodies (ātma-para-deheṣu), these fault-finders (abhyasūyakāḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: ego, the sense of 'I am the doer,' self-assertion
force, physical power, might
arrogance, insolence, haughtiness
desire, craving, lust
anger, wrath, rage
taking refuge in, depending upon, sheltering in
Me (mām, the Lord) in one's own (ātma) and others' (para) bodies (deheṣu)
intensely hating, despising, being hostile toward
fault-finders, those who envy and disparage, fault-mongers

commentary.dadaji: This verse reveals the innermost theological root of the āsurī condition: they hate God — not in abstract theological dispute, but in every human face they encounter, in every mirror they look into. For the Lord dwells in all hearts (Ch15 v15), and when one hates any being, one hates the Beloved who lives within that being. How many of us carry a trace of this 'pradviṣantaḥ' — not recognising God in the difficult person before us, the challenging situation around us? The remedy Sri Krishna will give us in the next chapters is the very opposite: sarva-bhūteṣu ātmānam — to see the Self in all beings.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This is the culminating verse in the description of the āsurī character, and it is theologically the most significant. 'Mām ātma-para-deheṣu pradviṣantaḥ' — they hate Me in their own and others' bodies — means that hatred of any being is hatred of Brahman, since Brahman is the indwelling Consciousness in all bodies. The Advaita teaching is implicit here: because there is only one Consciousness appearing as many, hatred of another is always ultimately hatred of one's own deepest Self. The āsurī soul, by fragmenting reality into enemies and possessions, wages war upon the very ground of its own being.
commentary.yogananda: The five-fold refuge of the āsurī soul — ego, force, arrogance, desire, anger — is the exact inversion of the divine qualities with which this chapter opens. And the fruit of this inverted refuge is the inability to perceive the Divine in anyone or anything. Yogananda taught that the spiritual eye, when open, sees the light of God in every face; the āsurī eye, clouded by these five veils, sees only competitors, instruments, and enemies. 'Abhyasūyakāḥ' — fault-finders — is the social expression of this spiritual blindness: the person who cannot perceive the sacred in others is compelled to denigrate them.
commentary.goyandka: This verse stands as the theological climax of the āsurī portrait. The five defects listed — ahaṅkāra, bala, darpa, kāma, krodha — are not random vices but a structured descent: ego (ahaṅkāra) produces the claim of independent power (bala), which, threatened, becomes arrogance (darpa), which, frustrated, becomes desire (kāma), which, blocked, becomes anger (krodha). 'Abhyasūyakāḥ' is the same term used in 3.31-32 for those who find fault with the Gita's teaching — linking this verse to a consistent pattern. The verse ends without a main verb — a syntactic break that commentators note points forward to v19 where Krishna delivers the consequence.

verses.sanskrit:
तान् अहं द्विषतः क्रूरान् संसारेषु नराधमान् ।
क्षिपाम्य् अजस्रम् अशुभान् आसुरीष्व् एव योनिषु ॥
verses.transliteration:
tān aham dviṣataḥ krūrān saṃsāreṣu narādhamān |
kṣipāmi ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣu eva yoniṣu ||
verses.translation: Those hate-filled (dviṣataḥ), cruel (krūrān), vilest of men (narādhamān), inauspicious ones (aśubhān) — I hurl them perpetually (ajasram kṣipāmi) into demoniac wombs (āsurīṣu yoniṣu) in the cycles of saṃsāra (saṃsāreṣu).

word_breakdown.meaning: them, those (referring to the āsurī souls of the preceding verse)
the hate-filled, those who are hostile, those who despise
the cruel, the harsh, the merciless
in the cycles of existence (saṃsāra), in repeated births and deaths
the vilest/lowest of men (nara = man; adhama = lowest)
I hurl, I cast, I throw (with force)
perpetually, continuously, without cessation, again and again
the inauspicious ones, those bereft of good karma
into demoniac wombs/births (āsurī = demoniac; yoni = womb, origin, birth-condition)

commentary.dadaji: Sri Krishna speaks here with the authority of cosmic law — and yet the devotee's heart understands this not as a wrathful God punishing enemies but as a loving Father describing the precise fruition of choices made in freedom. The āsurī soul has freely chosen hatred, cruelty, and the rejection of the Divine in all beings; the universe, sustained by the Lord's will, simply reflects those choices back in the form of āsurī births. The same Gita that contains this verse also tells us in Chapter 9 that even the most sinful can cross the ocean of evil by the raft of devotion. The door of bhakti is never closed.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse should be understood in the context of the Vedantic doctrine of karma and rebirth, not as an expression of divine vindictiveness. 'Kṣipāmi ajasram' — I hurl them perpetually — means that the Lord, as the cosmic administrator (jagad-īśvara), maintains the causal order: āsurī consciousness produces āsurī births, which reinforce āsurī tendencies, perpetuating the cycle. This is not punishment imposed from outside; it is the natural unfolding of the law of karma. 'Narādhamān' — the lowest of humans — corresponds to the 'mūḍha' (spiritually blind) category distinguished from the 'jijñāsu' and 'jñānī' in Chapter 7.
commentary.yogananda: Divine justice, in the Vedic-yogic understanding, is not retributive but redemptive — it works through the law of like attracting like. A consciousness soaked in hatred, cruelty, and delusion will naturally gravitate, after death, toward a birth-environment that matches its vibration. 'Āsurīṣu yoniṣu' — demoniac wombs — means environments, families, and circumstances that will reinforce and deepen those tendencies. Yet even here, in the darkest corner of saṃsāra, the Lord dwells as the inner guide. The very suffering of lower births is the universe's merciful pressure to eventually turn the soul Godward.
commentary.goyandka: This verse introduces the concept of yoni (womb, birth-condition) as the mechanism of karmic fruition, a teaching elaborated further in the dharmaśāstra literature. 'Āsurīṣv eva yoniṣu' — into demoniac births specifically — means that the āsurī consciousness does not simply take any birth but gravitates toward conditions that will perpetuate its own nature. The adverb 'ajasram' — perpetually, without break — emphasises the self-reinforcing nature of this cycle: unlike merit-based rebirths that gradually exhaust karma, the āsurī cycle is self-perpetuating because its defining feature (rejection of Brahman) prevents the very śraddhā that could reverse it. Verse 20 will complete this picture.

verses.sanskrit:
आसुरीं योनिम् आपन्ना मूढा जन्मनि जन्मनि ।
माम् अप्राप्यैव कौन्तेय ततो यान्त्य् अधमां गतिम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
āsurīm yonim āpannāḥ mūḍhāḥ janmani janmani |
mām aprāpya eva kaunteya tataḥ yānti adhamām gatim ||
verses.translation: Having fallen into demoniac wombs (āsurīṃ yonim āpannāḥ), deluded birth after birth (mūḍhāḥ janmani janmani) — not reaching Me at all (mām aprāpya eva), O Kaunteya — they then go to the lowest state (adhamāṃ gatim).

word_breakdown.meaning: having obtained/entered (āpannāḥ) the demoniac womb/birth-condition (āsurīm yonim)
the deluded, the foolish, the spiritually blind (from muḥ = to be confused)
birth after birth, in each successive birth, again and again
without ever reaching (aprāpya) Me (mām) at all (eva — emphatic)
O son of Kuntī (Arjuna's epithet, reminding him of his noble lineage)
from there they go, thereafter they proceed
the lowest destination (adhamā = most inferior; gati = movement, destination, state)

commentary.dadaji: Sri Krishna addresses Arjuna as 'Kaunteya' at this most solemn moment — 'O son of Kuntī.' This address carries a hidden message: Kunti was the embodiment of surrender and devotion. By addressing her son with her name at this juncture, Sri Krishna is subtly saying: 'Remember your inheritance — you are born of devotion, not of delusion. You are not these āsurī souls; you belong to the daivī sampat.' The phrase 'mām aprāpya eva' — without ever reaching Me — is the most tragic phrase in this passage. The final fall, 'adhamāṃ gatim,' is the outcome not of dramatic sin but of the steady habit of turning away from God.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse brings the āsurī portrait to its logical conclusion. 'Janmani janmani' — birth after birth — corresponds to what modern Vedantins describe as the samskaāra-laden causal body being carried through multiple lives, each impression deepening the groove of āsurī tendency. 'Mām aprāpya eva' is the most precise definition of saṃsāra: the state of existing without ever arriving at one's own deepest nature, the Ātman-Brahman. 'Adhamāṃ gatim' — the lowest state — is not merely a destination but a direction: the progressive contraction of consciousness away from its own infinite nature. This verse sets up the rescue operation of v21-24: the three gates of hell that the wise must abandon.
commentary.yogananda: Birth after birth, without once catching the fragrance of the Divine — this is the verse that most moved me when I first encountered it, because it shows the stakes of our spiritual choices. Yogananda taught that every human incarnation is an extraordinary opportunity, precisely because in the human form the soul has the capacity for self-reflection, devotion, and liberation. To waste it in the āsurī pattern — not once, but janmani janmani — is the deepest tragedy the Gita describes. Yet the very next section offers the key: identify and abandon the three gates of hell (kāma, krodha, lobha), follow the śāstric guidance, and the trajectory reverses toward the Divine.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is the culmination of the āsurī section (v6-20) and serves as the dark counterpart to the opening daivī portrait (v1-3). The phrase 'mām aprāpya eva' — without ever reaching Me — is the most theologically precise summary of the āsurī tragedy: it is not the accumulation of sin per se that constitutes damnation, but the structural incapacity, born of sustained āsurī living, to turn toward and receive the Lord. 'Adhamāṃ gatim' corresponds to what the dharmaśāstra describes as the lowest sub-human births. The transitional function of this verse is important: having completed the portrait of āsurī bondage, the Gita now turns, in the verses that follow, to prescribe the śāstric path as the means of escape — the direct antidote to the ajñāna-vimohitā condition described throughout this section.

commentary.dadaji: Kṛṣṇa now delivers a diagnosis of the deepest roots of the demoniac fall: not dozens of faults, but three. Kāma — the grasping desire that says 'I must have this' — is the seed. When kāma is frustrated, krodha explodes; when kāma is satisfied it multiplies into lobha, the hoarding that is never satisfied. These three are not merely moral failings; they are gates that lead the soul away from its own nature, its own śreyas. 'Nāśanam ātmanaḥ' — they destroy the very Self. The āsurī person described in this chapter was enslaved by all three. The instruction is stark and practical: tyajet — abandon them. Not suppress, not manage — abandon, as one drops a burning coal.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This is one of the most quoted verses in the Gītā and for good reason — it encapsulates the entire pathology of spiritual bondage in three words. Kāma is not ordinary desire but the compulsive, ego-driven craving that treats the world as existing for personal satisfaction. Krodha arises inevitably when that craving is thwarted — the ego, denied its object, erupts in rage. Lobha is kāma in its hoarding mode, the insistence that no amount is ever enough. Vedānta identifies kāma and krodha especially as the twin enemies of discrimination (viveka) and dispassion (vairāgya). The Lord calls them 'gates of hell' — not metaphorical fire, but the actual lived experience of a mind destroyed by its own compulsions, cut off from the light of ātman.
commentary.yogananda: Master explained that kāma, krodha, and lobha are the three distortions of the one life-force, prāṇa, when it turns outward and downward. Desire pulls prāṇa into the world of objects; anger violently discharges it when blocked; greed hoards it in the ego's treasury. The mystic's work is to redirect this very force upward through the spine — the reverse current that Kṛṣṇa speaks of when he describes the 'inverted aśvattha tree' of the previous chapter. To abandon the triad is not mere renunciation but a redirection: the energy of kāma becomes divine longing for God, krodha becomes zeal against spiritual ignorance, lobha becomes the fierce desire to accumulate divine qualities. This is the alchemy of the Gītā's practical teaching.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Kṛṣṇa here identifies the three primary gates through which a jīva enters the descending path of naraka — a condition of deep spiritual degradation. These three — kāma, krodha, lobha — are not separate vices but a single chain: unfulfilled desire breeds anger, satisfied desire breeds greed, and greed breeds more desire, completing the cycle. The Lord does not say 'reduce' or 'control' — He says tyajet, renounce them entirely. This is possible because the Self is by nature free of all three; they belong to the ego-mind, not to ātman. The sādhaka who clearly sees that these three are destructive of his very Self (nāśanam ātmanaḥ) naturally develops viveka sharp enough to step away from them, just as one who knows a path leads off a cliff does not debate whether to step forward.

commentary.dadaji: Notice how Kṛṣṇa restates these three not just as 'gates to hell' but as 'tamo-dvārāḥ' — gates of tamas, of darkness and inertia. They are gateways into a heavier, darker mode of being. The positive side of the coin is equally striking: freedom from these three is enough — the Lord does not demand extraordinary austerities or years of ritual. Simply released from kāma, krodha, and lobha, a person naturally begins to act in ways that benefit the real Self, not merely the ego. And from that, parāṃ gatim — the Supreme Destination — follows. This is Kṛṣṇa's compassionate assurance: the path need not be mysterious. Remove the three obstructions and the soul moves toward its natural home.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Kṛṣṇa now names the three gates from the positive direction: they are gates of tamas, of ignorance and heaviness. This is precise. Kāma obscures the light of discrimination (tamas over viveka); krodha clouds equanimity (tamas over sattva); lobha distorts the sense of what truly matters (tamas over wisdom). 'Ātmanaḥ śreyaḥ' is a crucial phrase — not merely what is pleasant or immediately gratifying (preyas), but what is genuinely good for the Self. The Kaṭhopaniṣad famously distinguishes śreyas from preyas; the person who chooses śreyas attains liberation, while one who chases preyas misses the goal. Here Kṛṣṇa says: freedom from the three gates is itself the turn from preyas to śreyas.
commentary.yogananda: The word 'vimuktaḥ' — released, freed — is significant. One does not simply walk away from kāma, krodha, and lobha by willpower alone; one is freed from them. This freedom comes through the grace that flows when the devotee sincerely turns toward God. When the three gates of darkness are closed, what opens? The interior light of the Self. 'Ācaraty ātmanaḥ śreyaḥ' — one begins to live according to what is truly good for the soul rather than what the ego craves. This is the spiritual life: not rigid rule-following but an interior alignment with one's own deepest nature. And from that alignment, parāṃ gatim — the Supreme — is not a distant destination but a natural culmination.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is the bright counterpart to verse 21. Having identified the disease (kāma, krodha, lobha as tamas-gates), Kṛṣṇa now describes health: a person freed from these three conducts himself according to what is truly good for the ātman, not according to ego-desire. The word 'ācarati' — practices, conducts — indicates that this is not a once-for-all event but a sustained way of living. When desire, anger, and greed no longer dictate action, dharma and śāstra naturally become the guide. The aspirant's actions progressively purify the antaḥkaraṇa (inner instrument), and this purification itself carries the jīva toward its supreme destination. Kṛṣṇa's promise is unconditional: wherever this liberation from the three gates occurs, parāṃ gatim follows.

commentary.dadaji: Kṛṣṇa now closes the loop: the person who discards śāstra and follows only personal desire is the very āsurī type described throughout this chapter. The triple negation is deliberate — 'na siddhi, na sukha, na parāṃ gatim' — neither worldly success, nor happiness even in this life, nor liberation. Many suppose that following desire at least brings happiness here even if not there. Kṛṣṇa says no: even ordinary sukha eludes the one who makes desire his only guide. This is a psychological truth as much as a spiritual one. The ego's endless wanting produces restlessness, not contentment. Without a standard beyond the self — without śāstra, without a teacher, without dharma — there is no stable ground from which any real attainment grows.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse directly names the failure-mode that chapters 2, 3, and 16 have circled around: the substitution of kāma for dharma as the criterion of action. 'Kāma-kārataḥ' is a compound of some precision — it means not merely 'acting from desire' but acting as though desire itself were the valid authority (kāra = maker, agent). The person who has displaced śāstra with his own wanting has lost his compass entirely. The three things not attained form a descending scale: first, siddhi (success in any undertaking that requires discipline and sustained effort), then sukha (even ordinary happiness), and finally parāṃ gatim (liberation). One who lives by whim alone can achieve none of these, because all three require the capacity to act against immediate impulse — and that capacity is precisely what śāstra cultivates.
commentary.yogananda: Master often said that the spiritual seeker who abandons the guidance of scripture and guru in favor of his own reasoning and desires has placed himself in a wilderness without a map. This verse confirms it: no siddhi, no sukha, no liberation. The word 'utsṛjya' — having abandoned — implies that the person once had access to scriptural wisdom but consciously set it aside. This is a grave choice. Desire, unguided by any higher standard, is self-referential and self-amplifying; it cannot correct itself. The śāstras and the satguru exist precisely to provide the external corrective that the desire-driven mind cannot supply from within. Freedom is not found by following desire wherever it leads; it is found by the gradual purification that śāstra and satsaṅga make possible.
commentary.goyandka: The triple negation here — na siddhi, na sukha, na parāṃ gatim — is among the most sobering statements in the entire Gītā. Many aspirants imagine that they can cherry-pick from scripture, accept what suits them and discard what does not, and still make progress. Śrī Kṛṣṇa directly refutes this. Śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya — having cast away scriptural guidance — and moving only by kāma-kārataḥ, one's own desire-driven judgment, leads to comprehensive failure. No spiritual power (siddhi), no genuine peace (sukha), and no liberation (parāṃ gati). The reason is subtle: desire-guided action reinforces the very ahaṃkāra that must be dissolved for any of these three to be attained. Without śāstra's corrective light, the ego remains in its darkness, mistaking agitation for aliveness and bondage for freedom.

commentary.dadaji: This is the closing verse of Chapter 16, and it is not merely a conclusion but a foundation. Kṛṣṇa has spent the entire chapter drawing the sharpest possible contrast: the daivī person acts from dharma, from śāstra, from God-awareness; the āsurī person acts from kāma, from ego, from the delusion that 'I am the Lord.' The chapter ends by addressing Arjuna directly — 'te,' for you — and placing in his hands the one instrument that distinguishes these two paths: śāstraṃ pramāṇam, scripture as the standard of knowledge and action. 'Pramāṇa' is a technical term from Indian epistemology meaning a valid means of knowing — perception, inference, and verbal testimony (śabda). Kṛṣṇa says: for determining kārya and akārya — what ought and ought not to be done — śāstra is your pramāṇa. Not personal feeling. Not social consensus. Not momentary desire. Scripture, received through lineage and lived through practice, is the compass. And then comes the most important word: 'jñātvā' — having understood. This is not blind obedience to the letter but genuine comprehension of the spirit of what the scriptures teach. When understanding is real, action (karma) follows naturally. 'Iha' — here, in this very world, in the life you are living right now — you should act. The entire teaching of Chapter 16 resolves into this: know the standard, understand it deeply, and act from that understanding. This is the divine nature in practice.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Chapter 16 opened with twenty-six divine qualities and closed with one instruction: make śāstra your pramāṇa. The symmetry is intentional. The twenty-six qualities are not arbitrary virtues but qualities of a person whose inner life is aligned with the deeper truth that śāstra reveals. Fearlessness comes from knowing the Self is indestructible. Compassion comes from seeing the one Self in all. Non-attachment comes from knowing that what is real cannot be lost. All of the daivī qualities flow from right understanding — and that understanding is mediated through the tradition of authentic scriptural revelation. 'Pramāṇam' is the pivotal word of the verse. In Vedānta, the question 'how do you know?' is never trivial. For matters of ātman and brahman — the very subjects the Gītā addresses — neither direct perception nor logical inference alone is sufficient. One needs śabda-pramāṇa: the testimony of those who have seen. Śāstra is that testimony, condensed and preserved across millennia. To substitute personal desire (kāma-kārataḥ, verse 23) for this living source of light is to navigate by darkness. Kṛṣṇa's final word to Arjuna — and to every seeker through Arjuna — is: return to this light, understand what it says, and act from that understanding, here and now.
commentary.yogananda: Master Yogananda taught that scripture, guru, and one's own direct experience form a triple cord of divine guidance, each confirming and deepening the others. This closing verse of Chapter 16 emphasizes the first strand: śāstraṃ pramāṇam, scripture as the foundational standard. Arjuna stood at a crossroads where personal feeling and familial emotion had overwhelmed dharmic clarity — which is precisely why the Gītā was spoken. Kṛṣṇa's answer, across eighteen chapters, is: realign with what is eternally true rather than with what ego and attachment demand in the moment. The word 'iha' — here, in this world — is significant. The teaching is not only for monks or renunciates or those in ideal conditions. It is for this battlefield, this family, this confusion, this life as it is. 'Jñātvā' — having truly understood — the action that follows is no longer merely rule-following but dharmic living: the outflow of genuine wisdom. When scripture is understood in its depth and acted upon with understanding, the practitioner begins to embody the daivī qualities the chapter began with — and the three gates of darkness named in verse 21 close naturally, because the light of wisdom leaves them no power.
commentary.goyandka: With this verse Śrī Kṛṣṇa brings the sixteenth chapter to its luminous conclusion, and it is a conclusion that serves as both summary and directive for the entire Gītā's practical teaching. 'Tasmāt' — therefore, in light of everything that has been shown: the beauty of the divine nature, the destructive spiral of the demoniac, the three gates of hell, the freedom available through their abandonment, and the total loss that befalls one who discards śāstra for desire. Therefore — śāstraṃ pramāṇam te. Let scripture be your pramāṇa. The word pramāṇa carries great weight in the darśana tradition. It means not merely a rule or guideline but a valid instrument of knowledge, as reliable in its domain as the eye is for perceiving form. In the domain of dharma — of kārya and akārya, of what truly ought and ought not to be done — no individual's desire-mind is a reliable instrument. Only śāstra, transmitted through authentic paramparā and lived by qualified teachers, can illuminate this domain correctly. 'Kāryākārya-vyavasthitau' — in determining what is duty and what is not — this is the arena where error is most costly, because it governs the entire course of a life. Arjuna's confusion at the start of the Gītā was precisely a confusion about kārya and akārya: should I fight or not? Kṛṣṇa's answer was not 'follow your feeling' but 'understand dharma.' Now, at the chapter's close, He crystallizes this: your guide for all such determinations is śāstra. 'Jñātvā śāstra-vidhānoktam' — after genuinely understanding what scripture has declared — then 'karma kartum ihārhasi' — you are fit to act, here, in the world. The sequence is essential: first knowledge, then action. Not impulsive action dressed in the language of duty, but action that has passed through the fire of genuine scriptural understanding. This is the kārya of a daivī person: not performance of duty mechanically, but living in alignment with the wisdom that śāstra carries — and in doing so, naturally embodying every one of the twenty-six divine qualities with which this great chapter began.
